original_text: A multi-physics description of a multiscale system is often referred to as a hybrid model. In fluid dynamics, a typical hybrid combines a molecular treatment (a micro model) with a continuum-fluid one (a macro model), with the aim of obtaining the accuracy of the former with the efficiency of the latter [1–4]. The micro and macro models generally have characteristic timescales that are very different, which means that time-accurate simulations can be extremely challenging: the size of the timestep required to make the micro model stable and accurate is so small that simulations over significant macro-scale time periods are intractable. If the system is scale-separated, a physical (as distinct from numerical) approximation can be made that enables the coupled models to advance at different rates (asynchronously) with negligible penalty on macro-scale accuracy. E et al. [5] were the first to introduce and implement this concept in a time-stepping method for coupled systems, referred to in the classification of Lockerby et al. [6] as a continuous asynchronous (CA) scheme (continuous since the micro and macro models advance without interruption [5]). In this paper we extend this idea to multiscale systems comprising an arbitrary number of coupled models.
original_translation: Una descripción de multi-física de un sistema multi-escala a menudo se conoce como un modelo híbrido. En dinámica de fluidos, un híbrido típico combina un tratamiento molecular (un modelo microscópico) con uno de fluido continuo (un modelo macroscópico), con el objetivo de obtener la precisión del primero con la eficiencia del segundo [1–4]. Los modelos micro y macro generalmente tienen escalas de tiempo características muy diferentes, lo que significa que las simulaciones precisas en el tiempo pueden ser extremadamente desafiantes: el tamaño del paso de tiempo requerido para que el modelo micro sea estable y preciso es tan pequeño que las simulaciones sobre períodos de tiempo macro significativos son inabordables. Si el sistema está separado por escalas, se puede realizar una aproximación física (diferente de la numérica) que permite que los modelos acoplados avancen a diferentes velocidades (de forma asincrónica) con un impacto insignificante en la precisión a macroescala. E et al. [5] fueron los primeros en introducir e implementar este concepto en un método de paso de tiempo para sistemas acoplados, referido en la clasificación de Lockerby et al. [6] como un esquema continuo asincrónico (CA) (continuo ya que los modelos micro y macro avanzan sin interrupción [5]). En este documento extendemos esta idea a sistemas multinivel que comprenden un número arbitrario de modelos acoplados.
original_sentences: A multi-physics description of a multiscale system is often referred to as a hybrid model.

In fluid dynamics, a typical hybrid combines a molecular treatment (a micro model) with a continuum-fluid one (a macro model), with the aim of obtaining the accuracy of the former with the efficiency of the latter [1–4].

The micro and macro models generally have characteristic timescales that are very different, which means that time-accurate simulations can be extremely challenging: the size of the timestep required to make the micro model stable and accurate is so small that simulations over significant macro-scale time periods are intractable.

If the system is scale-separated, a physical (as distinct from numerical) approximation can be made that enables the coupled models to advance at different rates (asynchronously) with negligible penalty on macro-scale accuracy.

E et al. [5] were the first to introduce and implement this concept in a time-stepping method for coupled systems, referred to in the classification of Lockerby et al. [6] as a continuous asynchronous (CA) scheme (continuous since the micro and macro models advance without interruption [5]).
In this paper we extend this idea to multiscale systems comprising an arbitrary number of coupled models.

The micro and macro models generally have characteristic timescales that are very different, which means that time-accurate simulations can be extremely challenging: the size of the timestep required to make the micro model stable and accurate is so small that simulations over significant macro-scale time periods are intractable.

If the system is scale-separated, a physical (as distinct from numerical) approximation can be made that enables the coupled models to advance at different rates (asynchronously) with negligible penalty on macro-scale accuracy.

E et al. [5] were the first to introduce and implement this concept in a time-stepping method for coupled systems, referred to in the classification of Lockerby et al. [6] as a continuous asynchronous (CA) scheme (continuous since the micro and macro models advance without interruption [5]).
In this paper we extend this idea to multiscale systems comprising an arbitrary number of coupled models.

In fluid dynamics, a typical hybrid combines a molecular treatment (a micro model) with a continuum-fluid one (a
macro model
), with the aim of obtaining the accuracy of the former with the efficiency of the latter [1–4].
translated_annotated_samples:
Output: En dinámica de fluidos, un híbrido típico combina un tratamiento molecular (un modelo micro) con uno de fluido continuo (un
modelo macro
), con el objetivo de obtener la precisión del primero con la eficiencia del segundo [1–4].
macro model.translated_text:
Una descripción de multi-física de un sistema multi-escala a menudo se conoce como un modelo híbrido. Output: En dinámica de fluidos, un híbrido típico combina un tratamiento molecular (un modelo micro) con uno de fluido continuo (un
modelo macro
), con el objetivo de obtener la precisión del primero con la eficiencia del segundo [1–4]. Los modelos micro y macro generalmente tienen escalas de tiempo características muy diferentes, lo que significa que las simulaciones precisas en el tiempo pueden ser extremadamente desafiantes: el tamaño del paso de tiempo requerido para que el modelo micro sea estable y preciso es tan pequeño que las simulaciones sobre períodos de tiempo macro significativos son inabordables. Si el sistema está separado por escalas, se puede realizar una aproximación física (diferente de la numérica) que permite que los modelos acoplados avancen a diferentes velocidades (de forma asincrónica) con un impacto insignificante en la precisión a macroescala. E et al. [5] fueron los primeros en introducir e implementar este concepto en un método de paso de tiempo para sistemas acoplados, referido en la clasificación de Lockerby et al. [6] como un esquema continuo asincrónico (CA) (continuo ya que los modelos micro y macro avanzan sin interrupción [5]). En este documento extendemos esta idea a sistemas multinivel que comprenden un número arbitrario de modelos acoplados.

is often referred to as a hybrid model.

In fluid dynamics, a typical hybrid combines a molecular treatment (a micro model) with a continuum-fluid one (a macro model), with the aim of obtaining the accuracy of the former with the efficiency of the latter [1–4].

The micro and macro models generally have characteristic timescales that are very different, which means that time-accurate simulations can be extremely challenging: the size of the timestep required to make the micro model stable and accurate is so small that simulations over significant macro-scale time periods are intractable.

If the system is scale-separated, a physical (as distinct from numerical) approximation can be made that enables the coupled models to advance at different rates (asynchronously) with negligible penalty on macro-scale accuracy.

E et al. [5] were the first to introduce and implement this concept in a time-stepping method for coupled systems, referred to in the classification of Lockerby et al. [6] as a continuous asynchronous (CA) scheme (continuous since the micro and macro models advance without interruption [5]).
In this paper we extend this idea to multiscale systems comprising an arbitrary number of coupled models.

time-stepping method for coupled systems.translated_key: método de pasos de tiempo para sistemas acoplados
original_annotated_sentences: A multi-physics description of a multiscale system is often referred to as a hybrid model.

In fluid dynamics, a typical hybrid combines a molecular treatment (a micro model) with a continuum-fluid one (a macro model), with the aim of obtaining the accuracy of the former with the efficiency of the latter [1–4].

The micro and macro models generally have characteristic timescales that are very different, which means that time-accurate simulations can be extremely challenging: the size of the timestep required to make the micro model stable and accurate is so small that simulations over significant macro-scale time periods are intractable.

If the system is scale-separated, a physical (as distinct from numerical) approximation can be made that enables the coupled models to advance at different rates (asynchronously) with negligible penalty on macro-scale accuracy.

E et al. [5] were the first to introduce and implement this concept in a
time-stepping method for coupled systems
, referred to in the classification of Lockerby et al. [6] as a continuous asynchronous (CA) scheme (continuous since the micro and macro models advance without interruption [5]).
In this paper we extend this idea to multiscale systems comprising an arbitrary number of coupled models.
original_annotated_samples:

translated_annotated_samples:
Output: E et al. [5] fueron los primeros en introducir e implementar este concepto en un
método de pasos de tiempo para sistemas acoplados
, referido en la clasificación de Lockerby et al. [6] como un esquema continuo asincrónico (CA) (continuo ya que los modelos micro y macro avanzan sin interrupción [5]).
time-stepping method for coupled systems.translated_text:
Una descripción de multi-física de un sistema multi-escala a menudo se conoce como un modelo híbrido. En dinámica de fluidos, un híbrido típico combina un tratamiento molecular (un modelo microscópico) con uno de fluido continuo (un modelo macroscópico), con el objetivo de obtener la precisión del primero con la eficiencia del segundo [1–4]. Los modelos micro y macro generalmente tienen escalas de tiempo características muy diferentes, lo que significa que las simulaciones precisas en el tiempo pueden ser extremadamente desafiantes: el tamaño del paso de tiempo requerido para que el modelo micro sea estable y preciso es tan pequeño que las simulaciones sobre períodos de tiempo macro significativos son inabordables. Si el sistema está separado por escalas, se puede realizar una aproximación física (diferente de la numérica) que permite que los modelos acoplados avancen a diferentes velocidades (de forma asincrónica) con un impacto insignificante en la precisión a macroescala. Output: E et al. [5] fueron los primeros en introducir e implementar este concepto en un
método de pasos de tiempo para sistemas acoplados
, referido en la clasificación de Lockerby et al. [6] como un esquema continuo asincrónico (CA) (continuo ya que los modelos micro y macro avanzan sin interrupción [5]). En este documento extendemos esta idea a sistemas multinivel que comprenden un número arbitrario de modelos acoplados.
